sizeEntry.name: Size:
entries: Small or Medium (Depends on Species of Origin)

entries.name: Lifespan
entries: Eventides have stopped aging, although their skin might still do so. Their life usually ends by another's hand.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} with a range of 60 feet

entries.name: Undead Nature
entries: Undead Nature. Not being truly alive grants you certain benefits:

items: You don't need to eat, drink, or breathe.
You are resistant to poison damage and have advantage on saving throws against being poisoned.
You don't require sleep and can't be magically put to sleep. To complete a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, you must spend 6 hours in a motionless, but conscious, state.

entries.name: Death Throes
entries: Knowing how it feels to die, you know how to ignore it to keep moving on. You don't fall {@condition Prone|XPHB}, and are only considered {@condition Paralyzed|XPHB}, while making death saving throws.

Additionally, after rolling a {@variantrule Death Saving Throw|XPHB} and not dying, you can take your turn as normal, temporarily not being {@condition Paralyzed|XPHB}. Taking damage during this turn will still impose a {@variantrule Death Saving Throw|XPHB} failure.

entries.name: Eventide Legacy
entries: You are part of an eventide legacy, which grants you a specific ability. Choose a legacy from the eventide legacy table below. You gain the benefit of your chosen legacy.

entries.caption: Eventide Legacy
rows: You may use an {@variantrule Action|XPHB} to touch a creature to end one of the following conditions on them: {@condition Blinded|XPHB}, {@condition Charmed|XPHB}, {@condition Deafened|XPHB}, or {@condition Frightened|XPHB}. You can use this feature a number of times, equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}, regaining all uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

Your fiendish connection allows you to bend luck to your own will. When you fail a {@variantrule D20 Test|XPHB}, you may roll a {@dice 1d4} to attempt to turn it into a success. You can use this feature a number of times, equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}, regaining all uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

Your presence can instil fear. As a Magic Action, extinguish all non-magical lights in a 5-foot emanation, originating from you. All creatures of your choice in that area must succeed a Wisdom {@variantrule Saving Throw|XPHB} against 8 + your Charisma modifier + your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}, or become {@condition Frightened|XPHB} for 1 minute. They may repeat the {@variantrule Saving Throw|XPHB} at the end of their turn. You can use this feature a number of times, equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}, regaining all uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

Your partial translucency allows you to more easily avoid taking {@variantrule Damage|XPHB}. When a creature, you can see within 30 feet, makes an {@variantrule Attack Roll|XPHB} against you and hits, you may use your reaction to force them to reroll it. You can use this feature a number of times, equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}, regaining all uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

items.name: Flying Speed (Angelic Legacy)
entries: You gain a {@variantrule Fly Speed|XPHB}, equal to half your walking speed (rounded down).

You can use this feature a number of times, equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}, regaining all uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

You can use this feature a number of times, equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}, regaining all uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

entries: Your presence can instil fear. As a Magic Action, extinguish all non-magical lights in a 5-foot emanation, originating from you. All creatures of your choice in that area must succeed a Wisdom {@variantrule Saving Throw|XPHB} against 8 + your Charisma modifier + your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}, or become {@condition Frightened|XPHB} for 1 minute. They may repeat the {@variantrule Saving Throw|XPHB} at the end of their turn. You can use this feature a number of times, equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}, regaining all uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

Eventides are born when a dying creature makes a deal with a psychopomp. In exchange for a longer life, they must aid the psychopomp in making other creatures move on when their time comes. However, getting life from them also means they can never truly feel like what it is to be alive, as eventides are no longer required to eat, drink, breathe, or sleep.

entries.name: Escape Death by Bringing Death
entries: An eventide is born when a creature has reached the end of their life too soon, often by the hand of others. In this moment, if the creature truly wishes to stay alive, the psychopomp bringing them to the afterlife might offer to grant that wish. In return for granting them a form of eternal life, the psychopomp shares a part of their burden with the eventide. An eventide is expected to help the psychopomp help creatures move on, whether that is by killing those who stay alive through unnatural means or by freeing spirits that have been trapped. If an eventide breaks this promise, then the psychopomp will personally end their life.

entries.name: Undead in Nature
entries: An eventide is not truly living; It is their deal with the psychopomp that keeps them in a form of undeath. Their appearance usually reflects their undead nature, often their skin will keep rotting. Additionally, eventides are always cold to the touch and their heart no longer beats. Due to their appearance, most species will instantly try to drive them away or run away themselves; Making them unwelcome in most civilisations. This behaviour is usually exaggerated because eventides are seen as harbingers of death, and most mortals don't want to be confronted by death.

entries.name: Eventide Adventurers
entries: Almost all eventides tend to be adventurers. Most simply because that is the easiest way to uphold their end of the bargain, by finding those unfortunate souls who need to move into the afterlife. Some have been forced into adventuring, due to not being welcome anywhere, due to their appearance. A small handful would be adventuring because that is the only way they can live their desired lives, while still managing to escape the wrath of the psychopomp they are betraying.

entries.name: Eventide Names
entries: Due to being created after already having had a lifetime, eventides often keep their original name. This name tends to adhere to the naming scheme that species uses. However, a select few believe that their bargain has changed them so much that they prefer to take up another name. This name is usually in the form of a title, which relates to what they are doing.

items.name: Eventide Names
entries: Black Death, Collector, Death, Deathbringer, Final Embrace, Grim Reaper, Muerta, Muerto, Soul Saviour, Ravenkeeper

entries.name: Eventide Legacies
entries: There are four different Eventide legacies, which are listed below:

items.name: Angelic Eventide
entries: An angelic eventide senses when and where a good creature has died, when they need guidance to go to the afterlife.
Angelic eventides typically have skin that remains flawless and doesn't rot and beautiful bright eyes. They also always have angelic wings. Some even have a halo.

items.name: Fiendish Eventide
entries: A fiendish eventide senses when and where an evil creature has died, when they are trying to avoid going to their afterlife.
Fiendish eventides inherit physical traits of the plane the psychopomp originates from. Typically, they get horns and dark eyes.

items.name: Reaping Eventide
entries: A reaping eventide senses when and where creatures are wrongfully prolonging their lives. They tend to hunt them down to end it for them.
Reaping eventides typically have quicker rotting skin, red glowing eyes, and their skeleton is more pronounced. Some have shadows following them, making their immediate area appear darker.

items.name: Spiritual Eventide
entries: A spiritual eventide senses when and where spirits have been wrongfully trapped. They tend to focus their efforts in freeing them, so they can move on.
Spiritual eventides typically are outlined by a white-blue glow, which makes them appear slightly translucent. Some have skin that is fully translucent, fully revealing their skeleton if not clothed.

sizeEntry.name: Size:
entries: Small or Medium (Depends on Species of Origin)

entries.name: Lifespan
entries: A genasi has the same maturity rate and lifespan as the species they originate from.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} with a range of 60 feet

entries.name: Genasi Lineage
entries: You are part of an eventide legacy, which grants you a specific ability. Choose a legacy from the eventide legacy table below. You gain the benefit of your chosen legacy.

When you reach character level 3 and 5, you learn a higher-level spell, as shown on the table. You always have that spell prepared. You can cast it once without a spell slot and regain the ability to cast it in that way when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You can also cast the spell using any spell slots you have of the appropriate level.

entries.caption: Genasi Lineage
rows: You can hold your breath indefinitely while you are not incapacitated. You know the {@spell Shocking Grasp|XPHB} cantrip.
Whenever you are forced to make a saving throw as a result of breathing something in, you have advantage. You know the {@spell Thaumaturgy|XPHB} cantrip.

You may throw dust into the eyes of another creature, within 10ft, as an {@action Attack|XPHB|Attack Action}. Make a ranged attack, using dexterity. On a hit the creature is {@condition Blinded|XPHB}, until the end of their next turn. You can use this feature a number of times, equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}, regaining all uses when you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You know the {@spell Dust Barrier|WoBrCa} cantrip.

You can move across difficult terrain without expending extra movement if you are using your walking speed on a solid surface. You know the {@spell Blade Ward|XPHB} cantrip, which you can cast using a {@variantrule Bonus Action|XPHB}, a number of times equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}. You regain all expended uses on a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}.

As a {@variantrule Reaction|XPHB}, upon being touched or hit by a melee attack within 5ft, you can deal fire damage to the creature, equal to two times your level. You can use this feature a number of times equal to your {@variantrule Proficiency|XPHB|Proficiency Bonus}, regaining all expended uses on a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You know the {@spell Produce Flame|XPHB} cantrip.
Your vision or movement is not hindered in snow, ice, or blizzards. You know the {@spell Ray of Frost|XPHB} cantrip.
You have advantage on saving throws against being {@condition Blinded|XPHB}. You know the {@spell Starry Wisp|XPHB} cantrip
You take no damage from non-magical lava or magma, and can move through it at the same pace as your walking speed. You know the {@spell Thaumaturgy|XPHB} cantrip.
You have advantage on saving throws and ability checks to resist being {@condition Grappled|XPHB} and {@condition Restrained|XPHB}. You know the {@spell Sticky Hold|WoBrCa} cantrip.
Your {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} range increases to 120 feet. You know the {@spell Chill Touch|XPHB} cantrip.
You can see through fog, smoke, and steam as if it wasn't there. You know the {@spell Boil Fluids|WoBrCa} cantrip.

Whenever you finish a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}, you may pick the level 1 ability from another genasi lineage (not the cantrip). Alternatively, you could roll a d12 to have it randomly change at the end of a {@variantrule Long Rest|XPHB}. You know the {@spell Sorcerous Burst|XPHB} cantrip.
You can breathe air and water and have a swimming speed equal to your walking speed. You know the {@spell Acid Splash|XPHB} cantrip.

Genasi are the people that are most connected to the elements of air, earth, fire, light, shadow, and water. These people's temperament often reflects the element they are associated with. For instance, fire genasi tend to be quick to anger or are always raring to do stuff, while water genasi are easier going, but are often regarded as selfish.

entries.name: Children of the Elements
entries: Genasi in one way or another directly descend from the planes of elemental chaos. Whether that is because the child was born in one of those planes, because strong elemental magic was used on the unborn child, or because they directly descend from a genie, all genasi will always be connected to the elemental planes. Most genasi are aware of how they became genasi, especially those born to genasi parents, but some will live their entire lives not knowing why they are the way they are.

entries.name: Eye of the Genies
entries: Even though some mortals have been in a romantic relationship with genies, most end abruptly when the mortal is with child, as the genies often see this as an unwanted accident. This is why most genasi have never met their genie parent. However, depending on the genie type, the relationship might be different. Air genasi children, born from Djinni, are more likely to still be in contact, as those are more likely to believe it was fate the child was born. Earth genasi, born from Dao, would have been tossed aside, as soon as their parent realised that a child isn't as precious as gold and gems. Fire genasi children, from Efreeti, usually were taken away, as their mortal parent would have protected them from a life of servitude. Light genasi children, born from Pari, often seek to break contact themselves, as their parent would coddle them too much. Shadow genasi children, born from Hamzadi, would likely just have found themselves neglected by their parent. Water genasi children, born from marid, would have been discarded as their parent would have considered them a stain on noble title.

entries.name: Wild and Confident
entries: Having inherited both the clueless stupidity from mortals and single mindedness from the elemental plane, genasi tend to rarely lack confidence. A lot of genasi believe that what they intend to do is possible. Their ideas of what is possible will depend on the nature of the element they are associated with. Air genasi tend to be more accepting and go with the flow. Earth genasi are more steadfast and materialistic. Fire genasi tend to be more brash and quick to act. Light genasi tend to be kind and always willing to lend a hand. Shadow genasi tend to be more pessimistic but usually don't care if failure would hurt. Water genasi usually only think of their own benefit.

entries.name: Genasi Adventurers
entries: Genasi can have multiple reasons to want to go adventuring. Some want to discover what led to them becoming a genasi. Some would like to find their genie parent, in order to figure out why they never bothered to try to care for them. Some wish to find others of their kind, as most are born from more mundane species. Yet, others were forced into a life of adventuring, because they are seen as a curse, demon, or something similar. Since genasi tend to be uncommon, they are often shunned by the rest of the more mundane species, which causes this forced adventurer lifestyle.

entries.name: Genasi Names
entries: Genasi can inherit the naming scheme used by the mundane species they are born into or they might use their own, especially when born in a genasi community. In such a community it is common to name their children using various words related to the element they are associated with. Their last name uses the same format as the first name.

items.name: Genasi Names
entries: Ash, Boulder, Breeze, Cloud, Drip, Ember, Frost, Gravel, Mire, Mist, Mud, Rain, Rock, Silt, Snow, Sprinkle, Warmth, Wave.

entries.name: Genasi Lineages
entries: There are thirteen different genasi lineages, which are listed below:

items.name: Air Genasi
entries: As an air genasi you were either subjected to a high dose of elemental air, at or before birth, or you are descended from a djinn.
Air genasi typically have light blue skin and eyes, and often cloud-like hair. Some air genasi speak with breathy voices, marked by a faint echo.

items.name: Ash Genasi
entries: As an ash genasi you were either subjected to a high dose of both elemental air and fire, at or before birth, or your parents are an air and fire genasi.
Ash genasi typically have soot-covered skin, ember-like eyes, and black hair with ember-coloured specks. Some ash genasi speak with a very raspy voice, almost as if they are a chain smoker.

items.name: Dust Genasi
entries: As a dust genasi you were either subjected to a high dose of both elemental air and earth, or your parents are an air and earth genasi.

RDust genasi typically have skin, eyes, and hair in earthen tones. The skin of some dust genasi is very soft to the touch, and often parts flake like dust, often causing them to leave places they stay in dusty.

items.name: Earth Genasi
entries: As an earth genasi you were either subjected to a high dose of elemental earth, at or before birth, or you are descended from a dao.

Earth genasi typically have skin, eyes, and hair in earthy tones. Some might have hair that is rough to the touch or constantly covered in dust. Some also have skin that has crystalline or rocklike textures.

items.name: Fire Genasi
entries: As a fire genasi you were either subjected to a high dose of elemental fire, at or before birth, or you are descended from an efreeti.

Fire genasi typically have flaming red, coal-black, or ash-grey skin. Their eyes always seem like there is a fire lit behind them. Their hair tends to resemble fire or is sometimes actual fire, which is warm to the touch, but otherwise harmless. Some may have embers falling from their hair, when the wind picks up.

items.name: Ice Genasi
entries: As an ice genasi you were either subjected to a high dose of both air and water, at or before birth, or their parents are an air and water genasi.

Ice Genasi typically have light blue skin, light eyes, and white hair. Some ice genasi become frosted over, in normal temperatures. Usually this starts in their hair, which often allows their hair to be positioned in unnatural ways.

items.name: Light Genasi
entries: As a light genasi you were either subjected to a high dose of elemental light, at or before birth, or you are descended from a pari.
Light genasi typically have light coloured skin, eyes, and hair. The air and eyes of some light genasi appear to give off light itself.

items.name: Magma Genasi
entries: As a magma genasi you were either subjected to a high dose of both elemental earth and fire, at or before birth, or your parents are an earth and fire genasi.
Magma genasi typically have skin and hair in dark earthy tones and ember-like eyes. The skin of some magma genasi pulses with lines of, what looks like, magma, spreading around like blood vessels.

items.name: Ooze Genasi
entries: As an ooze genasi you were either subjected to a high dose of both elemental earth and water, at or before birth, or your parents are an earth and water genasi.

Ooze genasi typically have skin, hair, and eyes in sickly colours. The hair is always very fatty to the touch. Some ooze genasi always have slimy skin, often leading to leaving a layer of slime behind on doorknobs.

items.name: Shadow Genasi
entries: As a shadow genasi you were either subjected to a high dose of elemental darkness, at or before birth, or you are descended from a hamzad.
Shadow genasi typically have dark coloured skin, eyes, and hair. The eyes and hair of some shadow genasi is so black that it appears as if no light can enter it.

items.name: Steam Genasi
entries: As a steam genasi you were either subjected to a high dose of both elemental fire and water, at or before birth, or your parents are a fire and water genasi.
Steam genasi typically have skin, eyes, and hair in blue-grey tones. Their hair almost always floats upward like steam. Some steam genasi will only produce steam when they sweat or cry.

items.name: Volatile Genasi
entries: As a volatile genasi you were either subjected to a high dose of both elemental light and shadow or all elements, or you have inherited traits from all 6 pure element genasi.

A volatile genasi either looks completely normal compared to the species they originate from, or they have features of all other genasi. Some volatile genasi's traits might even change on a day-to-day basis, as these genasi are highly unpredictable.

items.name: Water Genasi
entries: As a water genasi you were either subjected to a high dose of elemental water, at or before birth, or you are descended from a marid.

Water genasi typically have dark blue or deep green skin and eyes. Their hair typically resembles water or seafoam. Some genasi always have skin that is wet to the touch and leave behind wet spots if they are in one place for too long.

sizeEntry.name: Size:
entries: Small or Medium (Between 3 and 6 feet tall)

entries.name: Lifespan
entries: A kitsune lives 270 years on average, but some can live as long as 1000 years.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: You have {@sense Darkvision|XPHB} with a range of 60 feet

entries.name: Shapeshifting
entries: As an {@action Magic|XPHB|Magic Action}, using somatic components, you can transform into a tiny fox form, a tailless humanoid form, of the same size as your normal form, or back to your original form. Your statistics remain the same in all forms, with these exceptions:

items: You gain a bite unarmed attack, using Strength or Dexterity, which you can use in your original and fox form.
You can't speak in the fox form.
You gain the Keen Hearing and Smell trait, while in the fox form, which gives you advantage on Wisdom (Perception) checks that rely on hearing or smell.

entries.name: Kitsune Tails
entries: At level 1 you have one tail while in your original and fox form. You grow an additional tail each odd level after first, to a maximum of nine tails.

entries.name: Foxfire
entries: You can summon forth an eerie light known as foxfire in your hands, as a {@action Magic|XPHB|Magic Action}. This light gives off 20ft of dim light for 1 minute. The effect ends early when it is dispelled using {@spell Dispel Magic|XPHB} or a similar effect, dismissed by you (no action required), or by summoning another foxfire light. As part of the same action or by using another action you can make a ranged spell attack against a target within 30 feet, destroying the foxfire. On a hit the target takes {@damage 1d8} damage of the type determined by your lineage.
Choose Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma to use as your attack modifier, when you pick this species

entries.name: Higher-Level Damage
entries: The damage of this feature increases by {@damage 1d8} when you reach 5th level ({@damage 2d8}), and once again at 11th ({@damage 3d8}), and 17th ({@damage 4d8}).

entries.name: Kitsune Lineage
entries: You are part of a kitsune lineage that grants you specific kitsune abilities and a cantrip. When you choose a lineage, choose Intelligence, Wisdom, or Charisma to use as spellcasting ability for it. Choose a lineage from the kitsune lineages table:

entries.caption: Kitsune Lineage
rows: {@dice 1d6} + Dexterity or Strength modifier piercing damage
You learn the {@spell Earth Shaker|WoBrCa} cantrip.
{@dice 1} + Dexterity or Strength modifier piercing and {@dice 1d4} force damage
You learn the {@spell Minute Shift|WoBrCa} cantrip.
{@dice 1} + Dexterity or Strength modifier piercing and {@dice 1d4} fire damage
You learn the {@spell Control Flames|XGE} cantrip.
{@dice 1} + Dexterity or Strength modifier piercing and {@dice 1d4} acid damage
You learn the {@spell Shape Water|XGE} cantrip.
{@dice 1d6} + Dexterity or Strength modifier piercing damage
You learn the {@spell Wind Burst|WoBrCa} cantrip.
{@dice 1} + Dexterity or Strength modifier piercing and {@dice 1d4} necrotic damage
You learn the {@spell Minor Illusion|XPHB} cantrip.
{@dice 1} + Dexterity or Strength modifier piercing and {@dice 1d4} poison damage
You learn the {@spell Poison Spray|XPHB} cantrip.
{@dice 1} + Dexterity or Strength modifier piercing and {@dice 1d4} thunder damage
You learn the {@spell False Note|WoBrCa} cantrip.
{@dice 1} + Dexterity or Strength modifier piercing and {@dice 1d4} Lightning damage
You learn the {@spell Lightning Lure|TCE} cantrip.
{@dice 1d6} + Dexterity or Strength modifier piercing damage
You learn the {@spell Spectral Form|WoBrCa} cantrip.
{@dice 1} + Dexterity or Strength modifier piercing and {@dice 1d4} radiant damage
{@dice 1} + Dexterity or Strength modifier piercing and {@dice 1d4} cold damage
You learn the {@spell Wave of Protection|WoBrCa} cantrip.
{@dice 1} + Dexterity or Strength modifier piercing and {@dice 1d4} psychic damage
You learn the {@spell Fear Feed|WoBrCa} cantrip.

items.name: Bite (Chikyu Kitsune)
entries: When you take the unarmed {@action Attack|XPHB|Attack Action}, you can instead make a bite attack, which can use Dexterity of Strength. The damage is equal to {@damage 1d6} + Dexterity or Strength modifier piercing.
